Posts.Title: Insurance company will not cover my MRI blas dlb823

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 10:49AM abinneb wrote: Hey jennyr - welcome to a great place to get support and answers - you will find amazing help here. Sorry to hear that you've been through such a trying rollercoaster of a ride with this cancer sh&* - it is awful.   Bilateral is a tough decision to make and one only you can really make. My case was much less involved than yours and for me it was an easy decision because I didn't want to live with the 'axe waiting to fall' on the other side.  But each of us has to decide what we are able to do to have the best outcome we can.  I didn't have a choice on the right (cancer) side as it was all over and I am (well was I guess!) small breasted.  I felt strong that I had a choice to reduce my risk significantly by making having the bilateral.  I was blessed that I had overwhelming support for my decision and in the end, pathology on the 'non-cancer' side did show ADH.  So I feel even better that the choice I made was right for me.     I pray that you find peace to make your decision and feel strong and confident about your choice ~  feel free to pm me if you want - I'd be happy to share my experiences so far in relation to the bilateral. big hugs to you Amy

There are lots of threads in the forums with info about reconstuction and surgery.  They are so very helpful.  Please priv message me if you want and I can share my experience so far.  Best wishes to you! Amy Amy
Posts.Title: prophylactic mastectomy-your input wanted tweekerbeeker lilith

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2008 07:49AM abinneb wrote: Hi all - I have long hx of problematic 'difficult' to interpret mammos because of dense breasts.  2008 -calcs of suspicious nature found on digital mammo. Had biopsy and dcis found in one area of right breast. Thank goodness I had a nurse who worked in that area who my hsb knew.  I asked her advice and she  'find a surgeon who will do an MRI'. As no doc had suggested this,  I went home and surfed for info.  So, at the consult with the BS, we were thinking lumpectomy with rads.  I asked her about doing an MRI and she said no problem.  Had the MRI and she called me the next day and said she was very sorry but they had identified areas all over the breast - no longer just 9'o clock, but 6, 12, and 3'o clock  and a large area behind the nipple. It was devastating to hear.  We talked she recommended mastectomy on R side.  The MRI on left side, radiologist determined was 'B-9'.  After that point I decided to go with bilateral.  And post op path showed ADH in left breast;so for me, the choice of bilateral was fine.   I have personally thanked that nurse for her recommendation of the MRI and told her that I credit her with helping me make a good decision based on the outcome of the MRI. I think the controversy lies with using the MRI as a standard screening tool.  It does have false-positives. In my case, it helped me avoid going through a lumpectomy, not having clean margins, going back in again.   And then I have no idea what would have been happening with the left side.  My BS said we would have been right back there taking care of the left side next.  I'm just hoping that for the future, they will either refine the MRI or develop a new type of MRI-related testing that can be more definitive in helping with diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2008 10:11PM abinneb wrote: It might be individual to the doctor but more probably the Operating Room protocol.  My sheet also said no nail polish.  I asked my surgeon directly and she said just don't put fingernail polish on. I did a nice pearly almost neon bright pink.  A couple of preop staff liked the color!   You could try calling the hospital and ask to speak to staff in pre-op and ask them.  Might be worth a try.  I had a general anesthetic so I didn't put anything on my face (would be having mask, intubated) so my surgeon said okay to nail polish, but no to face stuff.  Best wishes on your surgery!  Amy

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2008 09:53AM abinneb wrote: Hi - so sorry about your fear of surgery.  But please, if it is real for you - it is what it is.  Don't be embarrassed about it, but please don't let it interfere with a healthy future.  Have you considered hypnosis?  I was able to listen to my hypnosis tape right up into the OR where they gave me my 'cocktail'.  Docs were very approving of it and it worked great for me.  Again, don't know if it would work for you but it may be an option.  See if you can find a hypnotherapist that may have some experience with hypnosis and anxiety/pain control.  It may work for you to be able to move forward with your decisions. Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2008 09:37AM abinneb wrote: Sorry - just wanted to clear things up!  My mother, and other family members,  suffer from Wittmaack-Ekbom's Syndrome a.k.a. RLS which is not an ailment that a drug company came up with.  She, my grandfather, one aunt and one uncle all had it many, many years before a drug company came along, as do 3 of 4 brothers and one sister.    My mother has suffered exhaustive sleep deprivation because of this.   Yes my family has heard of every possible link to mineral/vitamin deficencies and none have been found that have helped cure or treat this disease.   And yes, one of the drugs has helped one of my brothers, while others have had no results.  What I was commenting on was that Suzanne Somes made a very flip and off-hand comment about RLS.  I don't care if she feels drug companies 'come up' with ailments, she should not make offhand comments on something she knows nothing about.  I would never make an off hand comment about her treatment choices - I have no experience with her research, so I could not say one way or the other about her choices.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 09:03AM abinneb wrote: Hi LUv2sing I think we all feel overwhelmed at some point so just know you aren't alone.   There is GREAT information in the forum Tests/Treatments/SideEffects - look for Surgery:Before During After and there are many threads about preparing for surgery - physically, mentally, practical info about your house, for your significant other, etc.  But please feel free to ask any questions and almost anyone will jump in with help.  We are all here for you - can't be right with you but we can hold your hand online and send you hugs! Anything particular you're wondering about at this moment? You CAN do this and with your husband by your side you'll get through it! Amy
Posts.Title: Searching for support Luv2sing marvil

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 01:59PM abinneb wrote: Hey Luv Generally I believe it is the type and amount of surgery.  It seems that most surgeons place 2 to 4 drains.  I had 4.    They aren't painful - unless you happen to catch one or pull on it!!  So, don't do that!!!!  Please - ask any questions as you think of them.  People will jump in and help out how they can with their own experiences.  Can I ask - how is your husband with helping out in general?  Do you mean specifically knowing what to do as far as drains etc?  No one is an expert at it, but my husband, normally extremely queasy around needles or anything, was absolutely an angel.  He went to every appt with me right from the start.  He learned about the drains, took care of those, fed me, fetched for me, kept very good records of meds and symptoms, called the doc with any questions, ran to the store (even when I just wanted ice cream!).  He looked at my scars when I was still unable to do it.  He was comforting and kind and funny.  He held me when he had no words and just told me he loved me.  As far as knowing what to do - like around the house?  In my opinion - who cares.  Of course there are only the two of us, so I didn't have kids to worry about.  But for us - as long as he could fix food, clean the dishes and do some laundry, I didn't really care about the house.  I wasn't open to ANY visitors  (besides all our family is out of state) and didn't care about the house - till I felt much better!  I was very surprised at how much rest I needed even a few weeks out.  I still ended up napping a lot during the day because I had a hard time getting comfortable at night.  You will need rest and the least amount of stress that you can.  Do try to do what ever you can get done before surgery - shopping, cleaning, etc.  Get a ton of dvds and get lots of comfy pillows!!!!  Essential!  Please - again - ask away.  So many experiences here - and all the help we can give! Big hugs to you Amy
Posts.Title: Searching for support Luv2sing marvil

Amy
Posts.Title: Can anyone answer this Question? ozzie2 abinneb

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 09:21AM abinneb wrote: Hi Journey ~ You found a great place here - lots of info and you will feel surrounded by the support.  Wish I could help you more - I was told what kind of biopsy I would have right away.  I had a sterotactic core biopsy.  Did they say what kind they want to do?  When you know what type of biopsy I'm sure there will be tons of answers for you here.   People here are honest and upfront and you will get the actual truth (many sides of it!) here! I agree with you about getting the complete truth.  I don't know if it is so much a matter of not really telling the truth with docs, but I think a large part of the medical field has never been through some of this stuff themselves so they can only say what they know from books and such.  I think they need to ASK their own patients to be brutally honest about how things felt - physically, mentally and emotionally.  That way they would at least be able to say "I have been told this.."  I am lucky in that my BS did go through surgery and my PS actually said he couldn't say what it would be like on a personal level, he could tell me what his patients had told him.  Which I found honest and comforting.  Big hugs to you Journey - we've all been there and know what a crazy ride this can be.. Amy
Posts.Title: Biopsy question... Journey Journey

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 11:58AM abinneb wrote: Hi Firstmate - I too have this - in fact have had it for quite a long time, developing the growths mainly over trunk, mostly on back.  I do have two new tiny ones on my right side breast, but to me, I don't think it is more than coincidental.  My doc too isn't all that concerned, but we do keep a watch on them.  If I feel there is ANY change at all, I just call and they always fit me in for a couple mins so she can check on them.  I personally have not had any removed by a Dermatologist, although I've heard that you can.  Also heard they can grow back.  I've read that it is pretty common among those of us who have had significant sunburns at a young age.  Best wishes, Amy

Posts.Title: when can you wear clothes going on over head? rayhope sunflower45

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 12:41PM - edited Jan 25, 2009 12:43PM by abinneb LOL!   Don't think you're quite old enough - I just turned 50 on Friday.  If 47 pertains to birth year...you'd have been pretty young!!!  And also laughing - I lived in Michigan for most of my life - but being surrounded by water, you just kind of grow up out in the sun.  I don't think I'd heard of sunscreen till well into adulthood.  We used babyoil, tanning lotion, etc thinking sun was good for you....sheesh.  I actually had a burn once through a tshirt.  Very scary.   Exactly why my doc checks me routinely because of the chance of basal cell potential.  I think it is a good idea for everyone to see & check their bodies, be familiar with what a potential harmful growth looks like and be checked!  Ask your own physician to do a visual check if they don't!  It should be just as important as doing a self-breast exam!  AND - those of you using tanning beds - you aren't safe from this!  Amy   (Edited to add:) I'd like to have a twin!!

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 12:14PM abinneb wrote: Well, I have read that it is more common over the age of 40, not 60.  My doctor was not particularly surprised because I'm a redhead, fair skinned, freckled, and had some severe sun exposure when younger.  At a time before sun exposure was thought to be bad.  We were always out in the sun as kids - all day during the summer, in the pool, at the lake.   I stopped after about age 17 because I just gave up on getting a tan like my friends.  Amy
Posts.Title: Actinic keratosis after mastectomy firstmate abinneb

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 12:07PM - edited Jan 25, 2009 12:11PM by abinneb Yea, that is the problem!  Unfortunately, they take YEARS to develop in many cases and although current sun protection is the best for future skin, the past sunburns and such are the cause of lesions you are seeing now.  I also have them in places where I would not have had sunexposure.  I was told it is very rare for them to turn cancerous, but they should be on your agenda for routine visits with your doc.   If you family doc is not familiar with them, what they look like, what to look for as far as changes, definintely follow with a Dermatologist who is an expert and can monitor them. (edited to add:) Sorry Firstmate - don't have an answer as to why they would appear where there wasn't sun exposure.  Who knows with cell growth.  Maybe it appears at a defect or weakness in the dermis?   Maybe someone else on the board knows! Amy
Posts.Title: Actinic keratosis after mastectomy firstmate abinneb
